Additionally, many different countries, languages, ethnicities, and ages are represented. Through the internship process, students are required to work with two different populations, which help them to expand their knowledge base of facilitating healing among diverse individuals. As our field is still a burgeoning one, each student makes a commitment to becoming a pioneer to its development.         Selected Student Bios             Barbara Harrison   B.A. : Dramatic Art     Type of Student: Full Time    Biography:    Barbara grew up in New Jersey and pursued her BA in Dramatic Art at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. She then moved to NYC to pursue freelance stage directing for companies such as Ars Nova Theater, HERE Arts Center, Lark Play Development Center, ESPA Primary Stages. Barbara also worked as an assistant director - highlights include shows at Signature Theatre Company, Clubbed Thumb, and a 29 hour play development process at Manhattan Theatre Club. Barbara has studied theatre in Ireland, Scotland, and England. Currently, she is pursuing her M.A. in Drama Therapy at NYU-Steinhardt. Barbara is thrilled to be dedicating herself to a creative, integrative, and mindful career. www.barbaradanielle.com    Research Interests:    Chronic illness' influence on character development    Chronic illness' impact on familial roles and dynamics    Therapeutic Theatre's capacity to engage clients, artists, and general audiences          Darci Burch    BFA - Acting, Missouri State University (Magna Cum Laude in Honors College)    Type of Student : Full Time    Biography :    Darci was born and raised in southwest Missouri and received her BFA in Acting and a double Minor in Psychology from Missouri State University. She is also a Licensed Massage Therapist and feels her knowledge of the body has amplified her acting and theatre work.    Darci moved to Portland, Oregon, where she lived for 5 years, acting, working as an LMT, and working on various Creative Arts Therapy projects. She has an extensive history of work with children both as a teacher and a nanny and hopes to pursue work with children in hospital settings after graduation. She also has experience working with elderly clients in the massage setting and firmly believes that the body holds stories of which the mind is not conscious.    Darci is currently a Program Assistant at NYU and works for America Reads/Counts.    Research Interests:    Drama Therapy and Pain Reduction in Terminally Ill Children    Children in Hospital Settings    How the body is tied to our affect    Alzheimer patients working therapeutically with mind and body          Kat Lee   B. A. - English Literature (Phi Beta Kappa)    Type of Student : Full Time    Biography :    A Cleveland native, Kat graduated from Oberlin College in 2011. As an undergraduate, she studied dramatic literature, psychology, and theater arts. She devoured every acting course she could get her hands on, including: Shakespeare, clown, Lucid Body, Suzuki, Viewpoints, and Fitzmaurice Voice.    After graduating from Oberlin, Kat spent two years in New York pursuing acting on stage and film, and working as a nanny. As her interest in early development increased, she began seeking out graduate programs that might combine her diverse interests. Then she discovered drama therapy.    Kat is concluding her first year in the program. She will be completing her internships at Kid Esteem and Hackensack UMC Children's Hospital. She also works for the educational hip-hop company Flocabulary.    Research Interests:    Attachment intervention    Infancy & early childhood development    Treatment in hospital settings    Developmental Transformations    Projective techniques    Animal-assisted therapy          Wanning Jen   B.A. : Electrical Engineering    Type of Student: Full Time    Biography:    Wanning graduated with an electrical engineering degree from Colorado State University. After working three years in the semi-conductor industry, he finally decided to follow his heart, to be an actor. He went back to his hometown Taiwan. His work included Improvisation, off-Broadway and experimental film there. Through his acting experience, he became more creative and spontaneous. His work was therapeutic to him. In the end of 2012, he decided to study drama therapy to advocate the field. Since 2013 his passion has shifted from merely performing to using theatre as a means of healing. His vision is to promote drama therapy in Asia and to achieve personal growth and social change.    Research interests:    Adult    Children and adolescent    Therapeutic theatre and social change    Improvisation and drama therapy                    Department of Music and Performing Arts Professions - 35 W. 4th Street, Suite 1077 -  New York, NY 10012 -  212 998 5424    This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©    by New York University. Craig has extensive experience working with youth, adults, and families in shelters, community centers, hospitals, residential facilities, schools, and on Native American reservations. He is particularly active in the treatment of individuals and communities impacted by developmental, familial, interpersonal, and mass trauma.    Craig is presently in full-time private practice treating children, adolescents, adults and families in White Plains. He is contributing co-editor, with Anna Marie Weber, of Clinical Applications of Drama Therapy in Child and Adolescent Treatment and contributing editor of the 2011 book Engaging Boys in Treatment: Creative Approaches to the Therapy Process.    He serves on the Editorial Board for The Arts in Psychotherapy and the Editorial Committee for The International Journal of Group Psychotherapy. In addition, he co-chairs the Child & Adolescent Special Interest Group and the Community Outreach Task Force for the American Group Psychotherapy Association. He offers trainings both nationally and internationally, and also serves as adjunct faculty in the Expressive Therapies Ph.D. Program at Lesley University.
